metadata.title: Effect of nano additives (titanium and zirconium oxides) and diethyl ether on biodiesel-ethanol fuelled CI engine

sections.text:
ing TiO2 (Titanium oxide) nanoparticle, ZrO2 (Zirconium oxide) nanoparticle and DEE (Diethyl ether) additives. The test fuels used are a blend of biodiesel (80%) -ethanol (20%) (denoted as BE), a blend of BE with 25 ppm Titanium oxide nanoparticle (denoted as BE-Ti), a blend of BE with 25 ppm Zirconium oxide nanoparticle (denoted as BE-Zr) and a blend of BE with 50 ml Diethyl ether (denoted as BEDEE). Addition of nanoparticles increases the oxidation rate, reduces the light-off temperature and creates large contact surface area with the base fuel thereby enhancing the combustion with minimal emissions. Experimental results shown that addition of Titanium nanoparticles increased NOx, HC and smoke with lowered BSFC and CO. Whereas addition of Zirconium nanoparticles increases BSFC and HC emissions with lowered CO, CO2 and smoke emissions in comparison with BE blends. DEE addition to BE blends improved the heat release rate and increased HC, CO emissions were observed with lowered BSFC, NOx and smoke. Simultaneous reduction of NOx and smoke indicates the effect of DEE on Low temperature combustion (LTC).
Keywords: Combustion; Diethyl ether (DEE); Emission; Nano additives; Low temperature combustion (LTC) ----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Increasing fuel prices and depleting fossil fuel resources in recent years drawn attention towards the use of alternative fuel for diesel engines. The use of vegetable oil is popular, economic and implementable source among the various fuel alternatives.
Numerous research works were carried out using various biodiesels derived from karanji, jatropha curcas, pungamia pinnata, soya bean, sunflower, rapeseed, etc., and their influence in a compression ignition engine was studied [1-8].
Singh [9] evaluated the performance of an indirect diesel engine using unheated and heated Jatropha oil fuel blends. Results showed that, the brake thermal efficiency of heated Jatropha oil is higher than unheated oil. Also, BSFC and smoke emissions were drastically lower for heated Jatropha oil compared to unheated Jatropha oil.
Works were also briefed on effect of different nanoparticles like titanium oxide, aluminium oxide, cerium oxide, magnalium cobalt oxide, etc., in biodiesel blends and improved engine performance and emission characteristics in observed.
Prabhakar et al. [10] used ceramic material (TiO2) as a coat-
ing for piston crown in a diesel engine operating with pongamia methyl ester. Results showed that the BTE improved with reduced BSFC. HC and CO emission were reduced with slightly increased NO emissions.
Selvan et al. [11] investigated the effect of mixture of Cerium oxide (CeO2) and Carbon nanotube (CNT) in a single cylinder 4 stroke water cooled variable compression ratio engine using diesel-castor oil-ethanol blends. When blended at 25, 50 and 100 ppm of 32 nm sized CeO2 and 100 nm sized CNT, brake thermal efficiency and cylinder pressure is increased. Moreover, such a mixture of nano additives resulted in advanced peak pressure occurrence with a cleaner combustion (i.e. reduced exhaust gases).
Jung [12] found that suspension of nanoparticles in oxygenated fuel blends, especially methanol reduces the main global greenhouse gas (CO2). They revealed that addition of nano suspension could be a new cutting-edge technology for effective CO2 reduction in industrial systems including IGCC (Integrated gassification combined cycle). Based on this fact, a novel approach is made in this research in reducing CO2 by adding nano additives to biofuel blends.
Fangsuwannarak et al. [13] investigated the addition of TiO2 nanoparticles in a single cylinder water cooled engine with palm oil-biodiesel blends. They found that, addition of TiO2 at a dosage level of 0.1 and 0.2% to the biodiesel blends *Corresponding author. Tel.: +91 8939118102, Fax.: +91 4422357912 E-mail address: harishvenuresearch@gmail.com
† Recommended by Associate Editor Jeong Park © KSME & Springer 2016
reduced kinematic viscosity increased the cetane number with significant reduction in BSFC, CO, CO2 and NOx.
Sujith et al. [14] used cerium oxide nano additive in Jatropha biodiesel at a dosage level of 20-80 ppm and observed that, the viscosity and flash point increased for the blends. Also, they noticed that the brake thermal efficiency and HC emissions increased with significant NOx reduction.
Effect of Magnalium cobalt oxide nano additives on Jatropha biodiesel was studied by Ganesh et al. [15]. The particle size used was 38-70 nm in scale with dosing of 100 mg/l. As a result, they observed that specific energy consumption is reduced at part and full load conditions. Also, the brake thermal efficiency is improved with reduced HC and CO emissions.
Yilmaz [16] compared the performance and emission characteristics of a CI engine with biodiesel-ethanol and biodieselmethanol fuel blends at a blend ratio of 85% biodiesel -15% alcohol with varying intake air temperatures. He concluded that preheating of intake air could substantially reduce carbon dioxide and hydrocarbon emissions with slightly increased NOx emissions. He found that preheating has an impact in reducing the fuel consumption of alcohol blends.
Kannan et al. [17] investigated the use of ferric chloride as a fuel borne catalyst for waste cooking palm oil biodiesel. They added ferric chloride at a concentration of 20 micromole per litre. As a result, slight reduction in NOx is observed. Drastic reduction of CO and HC is also noticed at engine optimum operating condition of 280 bar injection pressure and 25.5 degree bTDC injection timing. Also, addition of the catalyst improved the cylinder pressure and heat release rate.
Jung et al. [18] studied the influence of cerium additive on the kinetics of ultrafine diesel particle oxidation. They have found that oxidation rate increases significantly when cerium nanoparticles added to fuel. They also concluded that addition of cerium had no effect on overall activation energy of the fuel mixture due to the presence of other metals in diesel particulate matter coming from lube oil.
Risha et al. [19] investigated the combustion behavior of nano-Aluminium (nAl). They observed that, as the diameter of the nanoparticle decreases, the mass-burning rates per unit area increases. They also revealed a relationship between burning rate and pressure which is linearly proportional. They achieved a mass-burning rate per unit area of 6.1 g/cm2 at a burning pressure of 4.3 MPa. Such significant surpassed levels of high energy were not reported earlier with any solid propellants as the authors concluded.
Gan et al. [20] observed the effect of nano aluminium and micro-sized aluminium particles over the combustion characteristics. They found that nano suspensions can remain stable for a much longer time than micron suspensions due to higher surface-to-volume ratio hence the interaction between particle surface and the surrounding liquid is strong enough to overcome differences in density. Also, they stated that five distinctive stages (preheating, classical combustion, micro explosion, surfactant flame, and droplet flame) were identified for a stabilized n-decane/nano-Al droplet, while only three distinctive
stages (preheating, classical combustion, and micro explosion) were identified for a stabilized n-decane/micron-Al with the same mass-based particle concentration and surfactant concentration.
Yang et al. [21] performed a modeling study on effect of ethanol addition in biodiesel with advanced fuel injection timing. Modelling and numerical simulation were done with varying ethanol concentration in a constant speed engine (2400 rpm) with different load conditions. Results indicated that, cylinder pressure and indicated thermal efficiency reduced as ethanol concentration in blend (% vol) increased due to prolonged ignition delay. As the ethanol concentration increases, increased CO and reduced NOx were observed.
Yilmaz [22] performed a comparative study on CI engine using biodiesel-ethanol and biodiesel-methanol fuel blends with blend ratios of 85% biodiesel and 15% diesel. He concluded that, in general, biodiesel-ethanol blends exhibits reduced NOx with increasing CO and HC emissions compared to diesel. Moreover, he proved that biodiesel-ethanol blends in engine perform better than biodiesel-methanol blends in improving the engine performance with minimal emissions. Hence, in this experiment ethanol is preferred instead methanol.
Devdatta et al. [23] used aluminium oxide nanofluids as water coolant in diesel generator. He identified that nanofluids produced using aluminium oxide nanoparticles possess superior convective heat transfer coefficient. Also, the efficiency of waste heat recovery heat exchanger increased considerably.
Kao et al. [24] performed tests in a diesel engine with aqueous aluminium nanofluid solution as an additive for diesel fuel. They revealed that addition of nano solution made a tremendous impact over the combustion heat released. Moreover, the smoke and NOx emissions were reduced.
Ali et al. [25] studied the effect of magnesium (Mg) and molybdenum (Mo) fuel additives in tall oil biodiesel. Additives are added at the rate of 4, 8 and 12 micromole per litre on test fuels. They revealed that adding these additives improved the fuel properties mainly flashpoint, pour point and viscosity. They also noticed that CO and smoke opacity reduced by addition of Mg and Mo additives. Slight reduction of BSFC is also evident due to enhanced catalytic activity of additives in biodiesel blends. Tewari et al. [26] investigated the effect of Multiwalled Carbon nanotube in biodiesel sourced from honge oil. Addition of MWCNT’s resulted in increased thermal efficiency, NOx with reduced CO and HC emissions.
Kim et al. [27] performed a comparative study of effect of Biodiesel fuel (BDF) and oxygenated additive EGBE (ethylene glycol mono-n-butyl ether) in a compression igniton diesel engine. Results showed that the BDF and the BDF-EGBE mix had significantly better smoke reduction than diesel. Also, with the use of BDF-EGBE mix in 10% EGR (Exhaust Gas Recirculation) simultaneous reduction of NOx and smoke is observed.
In this present experimentation, four fuel blends were prepared and fuelled in a compression ignition engine and their
performance and emission characteristics were analyzed. Titanium oxide and zirconium oxide nanoparticles were used. TiO2 possess 4000 K volatization temperature (Tvol) and Heat of formation (DHf) of -2459 kJ/mole. ZrO2 possess 4280 K, T vol and DHf of -1097 kJ/mole [28]. Since TiO2 and ZrO2 nanoparticles possess high volatization temperature and heat of formation, a fraction of 25 ppm is prepared and blended with the base fuel (BE). A blend of biodiesel (80%)-ethanol (20%) denoted as BE, a blend of biodiesel (80%)-ethanol (20%) with 50 ml Diethyl ether (DEE) denoted as BE-DEE, of biodiesel (80%)-ethanol (20%) with 25 ppm Titanium oxide nanoparticle denoted as BE-Ti, of biodiesel (80%)-ethanol (20%) with 25 ppm Zirconium oxide denoted as BE-Zr. It is to be understood that 50 ml Diethyl ether and 25 ppm nanoparticles are ignition enhancers and added in a small quantity so that their concentration is independent of the mixture percentage i.e., 50 ml diethyl ether addition, 25 ppm nanoparticles are blended with BE blends (biodiesel (80%)-ethanol (20%)). BE is taken as baseline test fuel and all the remaining fuel blends are compared with BE for optimizing the effective blend.

sections.heading: 2.1 Experimental fuels
sections.text: Jatropha seeds were processed, crushed and raw jatropha oil is extracted. The raw oil is transformed to jatropha biodiesel by a process named transesterification, where glycerin is obtained as by product along with jatropha methyl ester. Obtained jatropha biodiesel has high cetane number, high density, flash point and lower sulfur content compared to diesel. Ethanol used for the experimentation is industrial grade anhydrous ethanol. In order to understand effects of titanium oxide, zirconium oxide and diethyl ether additive on biodiesel-ethanol blend in detail, four kinds of fuels including BE, BE-Ti, BEZr, and BE-DEE were tested in this study. Main property of blending stocks and test fuels are given in Table 1.

sections.heading: 2.2 Experimental setup and procedure
sections.text:
Agricultural applications and mobile generators use single cylinder, kirloskar type, direct injection engine. Hence, a stationary diesel powered Kirloskar engine (Model: TAF-1 Make: Kirloskar) was employed for experimentation. The test
engine specifications were given in Table 2. The engine is connected to eddy current dynamometer with electrical resistance followed by a dynamometer controller. Exhaust gas concentrations (HC, NOx, CO, CO2 and O2) were measured through gas analyser. The specifications of gas analyser and other measuring instruments are listed in Table 3. Block diagram of installation and experimental setup is shown in Fig. 1.

sections.heading: 3.1 Cylinder pressure variation
sections.text:
Fig. 2 shows the variation of cylinder pressure with respect to crank angle for various blends. BE exhibits highest cylinder pressure of 70.21 bar, followed by 69.27 bar for BE-Ti, 67.79 bar for BE-Zr and 65.67 bar for BE-DEE. The main reason for BE to exhibit such a pressure is mainly accounted to the presence of pure ethanol without any additives. The alcohol content vaporizes quickly as the engine in cylinder temperature increases liberating all latent heat. Titanium oxide nanoparticle acts as an effective combustion catalyst and plays a major role in cylinder pressure as it ejects 69.27 bar (slightly lower
than BE blends).

sections.heading: 3.2 Heat release variation
sections.text:
Fig. 3 shows the heat release rate variation of various fuel blends with respect to crank angle. It is observed that, BE-Zr exhibits highest heat release rate of 63.243J followed by 62.75 J for BE-DEE, 61.15 J for BE and 59.24 J for BE-Ti. The main reason for zirconium additives liberating highest heat release could be attributed to complete burning of all the nanoparticles in fuel mixtures. This triggers the catalytic activity of the nanoparticle and thereby increases the combustion efficiency. Titanium oxide nanoparticles produced maximum combustion pressure (from Fig. 2), but still gives reduced heat
release rate. The sole reason for this could be the oxidation potential of titanium oxide at higher engine loads, where very less fuel is consumed by engine (from Fig. 4) and all the fuel is burnt completely due to more combustion time. Whereas, BE-Zr has very high BSFC and when more fuel is accumulated in combustion chamber, more heat release rate is obvious with reduced pressure.

sections.heading: 3.3 Brake specific fuel consumption
sections.text: Fig. 4 depicts the variation of brake specific fuel consumption of various fuel blends with respect to brake power. Initially, BE-DEE possess lowest BSFC of 0.4846 kg/kW-hr at 25% engine load condition and BE blend possess 0.5397 kg/kW-hr. This may be due to the influence of DEE in the amount of fuel supplied to maintain engine speed constant. DEE has high volatility and latent heat of vaporization which reduces the fuel consumption. At 75% engine load condition, lowest BSFC is recorded for BE blends. The main reason that could be attributed to this is the presence of pure ethanol in the fuel blend that helps in increased rate of combustion followed by lowest fuel consumption. Effect of titanium nano additive in BSFC is evident at engine running at full load, where it showed 0.2858 kg/kW-hr while rest of the blends possess slightly higher fuel consumption value. Titanium oxide nanoparticles act as combustion catalyst for BE blends in the presence of higher engine cylinder temperature and pressure.

sections.heading: 3.4 Nitrogen oxide variation
sections.text:
The variation of Nitrogen oxide emissions in diesel engines is clearly depicted in Fig. 5. Nitrogen oxides in diesel engines primarily depend upon in-cylinder temperature, oxygen content in the fuel and air fuel mixture ratio. From figure, we infer that nitrogen oxide emission increases gradually as the load increases. BE-DEE exhibits lowered NOx throughout the load.
This could be dedicated to high latent heat of vaporization of diethyl ether which enables Low temperature combustion (LTC). Titanium oxide nano additives play a major role in combustion process in higher engine loads. In lower load, nanoparticles doesn’t make much difference in performance and emissions. As the load increases, the nanoparticles starts
burning at very high engine temperature and acts as an oxygen buffer promoting complete combustion. Hence, BE-Ti exhibits highest NOx in comparison with rest of the blends.

sections.heading: 3.5 Carbon monoxide variation
sections.text:
The CO emissions variation of the test fuels with respect to Brake power at 1500 r/min is shown in Fig. 6. Carbon monoxide (CO) emissions from internal combustion engines are controlled primarily by the fuel-air equivalence ratio. Diesels, however, always operate well on the lean side of stoichiometric; CO emissions from diesel are low enough to be unimportant [29]. But, while considering alternate fuels CO emission plays a vital role because CO emissions are in equilibrium during the combustion process but lately it deviates from equilibrium during expansion stroke. With DEE addition, high CO is observed in lower loads compared to BE-Ti and BE-Zr. Incomplete combustion cannot be attributed for DEE added blends for increased CO emissions as the smoke levels are low at lower loads. The possible reason for increased CO is that, the addition of oxygenated blends promotes Low temperature combustion (LTC) even at higher loads and this temperature may not be sufficient for dissociation of CO2 into CO resulting in increased CO emission. Considering nano additives in BE, At lower engine loads reduction of CO and at higher engine loads slight increase in CO is observed comparing with neat BE blends. The possible reason could be that nanofuel mixture operates at lean mixture in comparison with neat BE blends. At higher engine loads, the presence of nano additives lowers the rate of combustion and slightly lowered rate of combustion
is evident from increased smoke opacity for BE-Ti. Whereas, for BE-Zr blend less smoke and slightly increased CO is observed. The in-cylinder temperature is not enough for burning the nano fuel mixture (i.e oxidation of Zirconium) at high loads resulting in slightly increased CO emissions.

sections.heading: 3.6 Hydrocarbon variation
sections.text:
Variation of Hydrocarbon (HC) emissions with respect to brake power is clearly indicated in the Fig. 7. Addition of DEE in BE blends would probably result in Low temperature combustion (LTC). This phenomenon is also likely to be responsible for HC being predominant around the cylinder walls compared to rest of the blends. Moreover, at lower loads, the combustion temperature is also less which cannot burn the nano blended BE blends (BE-Ti and BE-Zr). So it causes increase in HC in comparison with BE blends, where the presence of pure ethanol increased the combustion efficiency at all the loads.
At part loads, except BE blends all the fuel blends exhibited almost similar HC emissions. At 100% engine load condition, the engine combustion temperature would not be sufficiently high to burn down all the nanoparticles present in fuel blends (BE-Ti and BE-Zr) which would be the sole reason for sudden increase in HC at higher loads for the above said blends.

sections.heading: 3.7 Smoke opacity variation
sections.text:
Fig. 8 illustrates the variation of smoke with respect to brake power as the engine load increases. The smoke emissions are highest for BE-Ti, whereas lowest for BE-Zr. So, the presence of two different nano additives clearly makes an impact over combustion enhancement. From the engine combustion characteristics (Figs. 2 and 3), we infer that BE-Zr produces more amount of heat than any other blends, which signifies the complete burning of all the nanofuel mixture resulting in complete combustion and reduced smoke. Also, Titanium nanoparticles are not burnt effectively during the combustion. Some of the nanoparticle mixtures are released as UBHC (Unburned hydrocarbons) and at the same time less oxidation of soot particles of BE-Ti resulted in increased smoke as well.
BE-DEE exhibits lowered smoke at lower and part load conditions. But at higher engine loads, the smoke opacity increases to 4.04%. This is mainly due to more fuel entering in the combustion chamber and all the DEE mixtures cannot be combusted at this time resulting in increased smoke. Incomplete combustion cannot be attributed for BE-DEE because diethyl ether promotes Low temperature combustion (LTC) which is clear why smoke is predominant at higher loads.

sections.heading: 3.8 Carbon dioxide variation
sections.text:
Variation of CO2 emissions with respect to Brake power is shown clearly in Fig. 9. The figure indicates that, almost all the blends exhibits similar trends, but it is note-worthy that at lower engine loads, BE-Ti exhibits slightly lowered CO2 in comparison with rest of the blends due to lower in cylinder temperature and pressure which is not sufficient for CO oxidation.
Also, at lower loads the presence of nano additives does not make an impact due to less engine temperatures. Hence, BE exhibits improved CO2 indicating better combustion. At higher engine loads, all the blends possess almost similar range of CO2 emissions.

sections.heading: 4. Conclusion
sections.text:
In recent years, numerous nano additives such as CeO2 (cerium oxide), Al2O3 (aluminium oxide), MnO (manganese oxide), CuO (Copper oxide), MnO (Manganese oxide), CNT (Carbon nanotube), etc., were used as additives so far. But, these nano additives were not selected on any basis of physical,
chemical and combustion parameters on whole. At the same time, very few literatures focused on comparative study of two nanoparticles for same base fluid in combustion. Considering all the above perspectives, in the current research titanium and zirconium nanoparticles were synthesized and experimented since they possess high volatization temperature and heat of formation.
In the present work, biodiesel (80%)-ethanol (20%) blends (BE) were subjected to the influence of titanium nano additives of 25 ppm, zirconium nano additives of 25 ppm and diethyl ether (5%) and their performance and emissions were compared with pure BE blends. Based on experimentation, following results were obtained. Titanium oxide addition in BE blends improved the in-cylinder pressure and reduced heat release rate is observed. BSFC and CO reduced with increasing NOx, HC and smoke emissions. Zirconium oxide addition lowered the cylinder pressure with slightly increased heat release rate. Moreover, BSFC and HC emissions increased tremendously with lowered CO, CO2 and smoke emissions. NOx reduction is moderate. Diethyl ether addition improved the heat release characteristics with slightly lowered pressure. Increased HC and CO emissions with lowered BSFC, smoke and NOx emissions were obvious. Overall, BE-Ti reflects better performance and combustion characteristics with minimal emissions.
Nomenclature------------------------------------------------------------------------
BE : Biodiesel (80%) - ethanol (20%) BE-DEE : Biodiesel (80%) - ethanol (20%) with 50ml Diethyl ether TiO2 : Titanium oxide nanoparticle ZrO2 : Zirconium oxide nanoparticle BE-Ti : Biodiesel (80%) - ethanol (20%) with 25 ppm Titanium oxide nanoparticle BE-Zr : Biodiesel (80%) - ethanol (20%) with 25 ppm Zirconium oxide nanoparticle BSFC : Brake specific fuel consumption DEE : Diethyl ether CO2 : Carbon dioxide NOx : Nitrogen oxide HC : Hydrocarbon CO : Carbon monoxide

metadata.abstractText: The present work is dedicated to the comparative experimental study of biodiesel-ethanol blends in a compression ignition engine using TiO2 (Titanium oxide) nanoparticle, ZrO2 (Zirconium oxide) nanoparticle and DEE (Diethyl ether) additives. The test fuels used are a blend of biodiesel (80%) -ethanol (20%) (denoted as BE), a blend of BE with 25 ppm Titanium oxide nanoparticle (denoted as BE-Ti), a blend of BE with 25 ppm Zirconium oxide nanoparticle (denoted as BE-Zr) and a blend of BE with 50 ml Diethyl ether (denoted as BEDEE). Addition of nanoparticles increases the oxidation rate, reduces the light-off temperature and creates large contact surface area with the base fuel thereby enhancing the combustion with minimal emissions. Experimental results shown that addition of Titanium nanoparticles increased NOx, HC and smoke with lowered BSFC and CO. Whereas addition of Zirconium nanoparticles increases BSFC and HC emissions with lowered CO, CO2 and smoke emissions in comparison with BE blends. DEE addition to BE blends improved the heat release rate and increased HC, CO emissions were observed with lowered BSFC, NOx and smoke. Simultaneous reduction of NOx and smoke indicates the effect of DEE on Low temperature combustion (LTC).
